title: 105_hr3212
content: The "Court of Veterans Appeals Act of 1998" allows the Court to prescribe rules and regulations under Section 7254. Additionally, it addresses the calculation of years of service as a judge. SEC. 102 amends Section 7296(b) to specify that only years of service as a judge of the Court shall be credited for calculating an individual's service. Fractional years less than 6 months are disregarded, while 6 months or more are counted as a full year. SEC. 103 limits cost-of-living adjustments to retired pay. Section 7296 is amended to limit cost-of-living adjustments to retired pay for judges of the Court, ensuring that their pay does not exceed the annual rate of pay for the chief judge. Section 7296 limits cost-of-living adjustments for retired judges of the Court to prevent their pay from exceeding the annual rate for the chief judge. Adjustments can only be made to ensure retired pay does not exceed the specified rate. SEC. 104. SURVIVOR ANNUITIES. Amendment to section 7297 allows judges to reduce contributions to their retirement fund after retiring. The amendment specifies the percentage of salary and retired pay judges need to contribute based on their status. This amendment will take effect on January 1, 1995. The amendment to section 7297, effective January 1, 1995, allows judges who have previously served to be exempt from interest payments during periods of separation from service or when not receiving retired pay. The amendment to section 7297 allows judges to receive annuity benefits if they die as a result of an assassination, with a survivor entitled to benefits. Additionally, judges in active service or retired under section 7296 are exempt from interest payments during periods of separation from service or when not receiving retired pay. The amendment to section 7297 defines "assassination" as the killing of a judge motivated by the performance of official duties. Changes include adjusting the age requirement for surviving spouses and increasing survivor annuities in line with Judicial Survivors' Annuities Fund adjustments. SEC. 105 exempts the retirement fund from sequestration orders. SEC. 106 limits activities of retired judges. SEC. 106 limits activities of retired judges by forfeiting their retired pay if they represent clients in claims related to veterans' benefits against the United States or its agencies. Title II introduces limitations on the activities of retired judges, specifically focusing on staggered retirement and recall provisions. Retirement is authorized for one eligible judge each year from 1999 to 2003. An eligible judge must be an associate judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims with at least 10 years of service, have made an election for retired pay, have at least 20 years of allowable service, be at least 55 years old, and have years of service creditable. Retirement eligibility criteria for judges of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims include being at least 55 years old, having at least 10 years of service, and providing written notice of retirement by April 1 of the specified year. If multiple judges are eligible to retire in the same year, the judge with the most seniority will be the one to retire. A judge eligible for retirement must provide written notice by April 1, which is irrevocable. Upon retirement, the judge must retire during the fiscal year of notice but not earlier than 90 days after providing notice. The retired pay rate is determined based on years of service as a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. The retirement pay rate for a judge of the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims is determined based on years of service and the judge's age. The actuary plays a role in calculating the present value for retirement fund payments. SEC. 202. RECALL OF RETIRED JUDGES. Section 7257 allows retired judges of the Court of Veterans Appeals to be recalled for further service upon providing written notice to the chief judge. The chief judge can recall a retired judge for a determined period based on expected substantial service. Retired judges of the Court of Veterans Appeals can be recalled for further service by the chief judge for a necessary period with written agreement. Recalled judges have the same powers and duties as active judges and are paid at the rate of active judges, minus their retired pay. Retired judges of the Court of Veterans Appeals can be recalled for further service under specific provisions. They are considered reemployed annuitants under certain chapters of title 5. This does not affect their right to serve as reemployed annuitants according to title 5. The United States Court of Veterans Appeals is renamed as the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims. Section 7251 is amended to reflect this change. Conforming amendments are also made. The sections in Title 38 are amended to replace "Court of Veterans Appeals" with "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims" in various sections and headings. The item relating to section 7286 is amended to read as follows: The amendments include changes to sections 7291 and 7298, as well as the heading of chapter 72 to "UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR VETERANS CLAIMS." The United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims is amended by changing references from "Court of Veterans Appeals" to "Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims" in various sections of different laws. This includes amending the heading of section 8440d of title 5, United States Code. The item in the table of sections at the beginning of chapter 84 of title 5, United States Code is amended to read as follows: "Claims". The United States Court of Veterans Appeals is now referred to as the United States Court of Appeals for Veterans Claims in all legal references.
